channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: After plea deals are canceled, what happens next with the Guantanamo 9/11 trials?
item.description: Georgetown University Law professor Stephen Vladeck explains where things stand with the 9/11 Guantanamo cases now that the plea deals have been canceled.

item.title: Was the streetcar revival a success?
item.description: It's been more than a decade that several cities got federal funding for downtown streetcars. Some have flourished, others are faltering and at least one is fading out.

item.title: What Hollywood gets right about journalism movies
item.description: NPR journalists Scott Detrow, Sacha Pfeiffer and Linda Holmes discuss Hollywood's treatment of journalism movies and how they reflect public perception of the profession.

item.title: Is the government's freeze of Harvard's federally funded research grants legal?
item.description: Lawyers for Harvard University and the Trump administration are set to begin arguing a case over federal funding for research grants.

item.title: Transformation in the Atacama Desert as a religious festival attracts thousands of worshippers
item.description:
Up on the high plains of the Atacama Desert, Chile's largest religious festival brings tens of thousands of worshippers together for a Catholic celebration with a twist.
Up on the high plains of the Atacama Desert, Chile's largest religious festival brings tens of thousands of worshippers together for a Catholic celebration with a twist.

item.title: Argentina's stolen children grapple with finding their place in history
item.description: Haley Cohen Gilliland talks about her book, "A Flower Traveled In My Blood," about the work of the Abuelas of the Plaza de Mayo and how Argentina's stolen children have grappled with finding their place in history.

item.title: Jane Austen fans mark 250 years since the writer's birth with a wave of parties
item.description: Jane Austen fans are celebrating 250 years since the writer's birth with a series of celebrations â€“ including Georgian costume balls, where attendees try out period dancing.

item.title: American singer-songwriter GIVEON on Beloved, a soundtrack of life's moments
item.description: American singer-songwriter GIVEON speaks with NPR about his highly anticipated new album, Beloved.

item.title: Examining the role of men in the gender gap in American society
item.description: The latest season of the podcast "Unsettled" from Iowa Public Radio looks at how gender affects people's everyday lives.

item.title: A surprise twist in the Trump administration's use of third country deportations
item.description: Chris Camponovo, a former State Department lawyer, examines what a multi-national prisoner swap says about the Trump administration's third country deportation strategy.
